author: Special Correspondent
text:
The Forest Department has begun seizure of wildlife body parts and trophies kept as antique possessions by private individuals. This is aimed at bringing down the value of such trophies in a bid to curb poaching.

As part of the drive, the Forest Department has seized heads, teeth, deer antlers and elephant tusks from private parties who were in possession of the same without any valid licence or documentation.

Destroyed

Such wildlife body parts and trophies which are in possession of the Forest Department are being destroyed. This is being done to generate awareness that such trophies are no longer prized possessions and also that they do not have any economic value.

Teeth and claws of leopards, numbering around 40, were destroyed by setting fire in the presence of NGOs at the Deer Park Guest House of the Forest Department on Wednesday.

Field Director of Mudumalai Tiger Reserve Srinivas R. Reddy said that wildlife body parts and trophies of those wildlife that had a natural death seized from poachers are with the MTR authorities.

Request

Of these, Wellington Defence authorities have made a request for eight elephant tusks, measuring about 2 metres, and on obtaining the consent and permission of the Principal Chief Conservator of Forests, the tusks will be handed over to the Wellington Defence centre.
title: Forest Department bid to curb poaching
